courses.description: Interdisciplinary seminar on cultural movements, figures, and art forms of the modern period from the Baroque to the present.  Focus on the West with some global comparison.  Emphasis on theoretical perspectives, methods, and research techniques germane to the liberal arts.
courses.course name: Culture and Expression: The Modern Period.

courses.term: Cross Listed: THEA 204; only one may be counted for credit.
courses.description: Study of the relationship between discourses of culture, politics, aesthetics, and live performance. Critical theories drawn from new methodology and ideologies will be applied to theatrical representations, both classical and contemporary.
Examination of the role of the Judeo-Christian apocalypse in the creation of modern realms of discourse, including political thought, modern science, and secular values generally.
courses.course name: Politics in the Age of Antichrist: Prophecy and Society, 1500-1800

courses.term: ; only one may be counted for credit.
courses.description: Exploration of the relationships and roles of women and men in the context of religious life.  May focus extensively on one or more particular religious traditions cross-culturally, or draw on a wider spectrum of examples.  Special attention paid to the complementary nature of men's and women's roles in many religious traditions; and also the way that male perspectives have dominated many areas of formal religious discourse, noting the dissenting voices of women often hidden in more informal types of expression.
courses.course name: Gender and Religion in Cross-Cultural Perspective

courses.term: Cross Listed: PSYC 296M; only one may be counted for credit.
courses.description: Examines the presentation of psychological themes in contemporary feature films. It will consider such topics as: Adolescence, Adulthood and Aging, Homosexuality, Drug Addiction, and Physical Disability as they are portrayed in films created for a mass market.
Study and analysis of uniquely American cultural patterns, social institutions, and core values, and how they are perceived both in America and abroad.
courses.course name: Images of America at Home and Abroad

courses.description: Examines two of the more creative literary genres that make up the canonical and deuterocanonical literature of the Jewish and Christian Bibles.  Both the historical and theological underpinnings of wisdom and apocalyptic writing will be explored in-depth, with some consideration given to literary analogues in Egyptian, Mesopotamian and Greek cultures.   Significant research into wisdom and apocalyptic writings outside of the testament framework required.

Philosophic investigation of moral problems in the medical world, including decision making, rights and values pertaining to human life, and the principles of justice applied to the health care field.

Analytical study of the Nazi extermination of European Jewry, with particular emphasis given to the roots of exterminationist anti-Semitism, and to the cultural response of Jews and non-Jews to the tragedy of mass-murder.
